review.title: Extensions of Simple Conceptual Graphs: the Complexity of Rules and Constraints
review.abstract: Simple conceptual graphs are considered as the kernel of most knowledge representation formalisms built upon Sowa's model. Reasoning in this model can be expressed by a graph homomorphism called projection, whose semantics is usually given in terms of positive, conjunctive, existential FOL. We present here a family of extensions of this model, based on rules and constraints, keeping graph homomorphism as the basic operation. We focus on the formal definitions of the different models obtained, including their operational semantics and relationships with FOL, and we analyze the decidability and complexity of the associated problems (consistency and deduction). As soon as rules are involved in reasonings, these problems are not decidable, but we exhibit a condition under which they fall in the polynomial hierarchy. These results extend and complete the ones already published by the authors. Moreover we systematically study the complexity of some particular cases obtained by restricting the form of constraints and/or rules.

sections.heading: 9. Con lusion
sections.text: We have proposed a family of models that can be regarded as the basis of a generi-based modeling framework. The main characteristics of this framework are the following: a distinction between different types of knowledge that can be reconciled well with intuitive categories, a uniform graph-based language that retains essential characteristics of the SG model, namely readability of obje ts as well as argumentation. We appreciate that this latter point is particularly important for the usability of any knowledge-based system. In our framework, all types of knowledge are easy to interpret, and argumentations can be graphically represented in a natural way using the graphs themselves, which the user can use his own modeling.
